Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 02:28PM mdoak wrote: ugh, three to four business days! I'm sorry Janet, and there's a weekend in here too. Do you have any friends around you can talk to? When I had my most recent breast scare in December we told some close friends and they were a wonderful support. Distraction, distraction, distraction! Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: waiting for diagnostic mammogram and scared Janet23 mdoak

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 05:06AM mdoak wrote: Hi there, Fibroadenomas are benign. I am wondering why they labelled yours "complex." Given your family history, the doctor will want to excise any mass that grows to make sure it's not cancer. Another possibility is that it's a phyllodes tumor -- hard to distinguish from a fibroadenoma even with a core biopsy, and almost impossible with a fine needle. Phyllodes are usually benign as well, though. So there are lots of possibilities of what it could be, most of them benign -- a strange-acting fibroadenoma (I had one of those recently), a phyllodes tumor (almost always benign, but they grow and need to be excised), and it is possible it's cancer. Keep us posted. And by the way, the excisional biopsy won't be bad at all. I personally have found the core biopsy to be more difficult. Melissa
Posts.Title: Not sure about fibroadenoma dobiedame dobiedame

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 06:58AM mdoak wrote: nwb, I had a biopsy of a BIRADS 4b lump in December and it came back benign. My radiologist was quite surprised and had pathology double-check the results. Just so you know -- you are just as likely to have a benign result as a malignant result.  What really helped me when I was waiting was telling my family and the people closest to me. Sure, they were worried, but they were also incredibly supportive. My parents were especially supportive, even though I know they were worried sick. I don't know how I would have gotten through without them. Everyone is different with how comfortable they are sharing these things, but you sure could use some attention and care right now. By the way, new posters can only post 5 times a day to reduce spam on the board. But you can private message anyone as many times per day as you want. Keep checking in and let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Waiting to have ultrasound guided biopsy nwb123 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 02:03PM mdoak wrote: Hi Ruby, I have tons of fibroadenomas, and thus far my radiologist has not wanted to order an MRI despite my extremely dense breast tissue because, in his words, I would "light up like a Christmas tree." I guess MRIs are not great at distinguishing cancer from fibroadenomas -- hence the false positives. However, he was going to give me an MRI if my last biopsy had been malignant, to help see, also in his words "the extent of her disease." I am left wondering about MRI as well. If you don't think it would be helpful detecting cancer given all of my fibroadenomas, why would it be helpful in finding more cancer once you have found it?  I am going to a high risk clinic in February -- my fibroadenomas don't increase my risk much, but the fact that I had ADH on one of these biopsies once upon a time does. Thankfully, once you're accepted there, they say insurance will generally pay for what they recommend, and I"m hoping they recommend an MRI. I'm more afraid of my dense breasts hiding cancer than I am an occasional false positive. I wish I had pressed my current radiologist for more information on this. If you happen to find out anything more, do post! Melissa
Posts.Title: questions for surgeon ruby5298 mdoak

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 05:39AM mdoak wrote: When they do biopsies, they go at them from the side, to avoid puncturing your lung. So the path from the nick in your skin to the place they're biopsying will be parallel to the chest wall. Does this make what they did make more sense? It's hard to tell from your description.
Posts.Title: Needle biopsy questions frazzledmom marie5890

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 06:01AM mdoak wrote: If you have a hysterectomy, search until you find a doctor who can do it laparoscopically. You won't need a catheter. I had a laparoscopic hysterectomy for endometriosis, and unfortunately had it on my bladder. I would have gone home that very day except I couldn't urinate and then had to have a catheter placed. I am very sensitive to needles and such, but the nurse was amazing and the catheter placement was no big deal, honestly. But again, I wouldn't have needed it at all had my bladder not been in shock from the surgery. :).
Posts.Title: BRCA1 + and need advice msv1984 CandDsMom

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 10:42PM mdoak wrote: Hello Janet! Thank goodness you have a mammogram on Friday. I can completely relate to the worry, and also completely relate to having difficulty getting medical people to take us seriously. Sometimes I think that's the female condition, to be not taken seriously by doctors regardless of what we present with. I've been concerned about my right breast since last october--the doc found a lump that looked suspicious and it turned out to be benign, but no one has explained other lumps, pain, and swelling in that breast. I went back a couple times and now am just sitting on my hands until June, when I have a screening MRI scheduled because I scraped in over the line at high-risk when I insisted they plug me into their model.   What you describe sounds like it could be concerning for inflammatory breast cancer, which from what I've read on here doesn't show up well on either mammogram or ultrasound. Since you're having a diagnostic, I assume you'll talk to a radiologist. If nothing is seen on the mammogram, can you ask him or her to rule out inflammatory? I think punch biopsies are the only way. The place where I go for imaging they do biopsies right on the spot for suspicious findings, although I think that's kind of rare. But you could push. Let us know how it goes, okay? And keep posting before your appointment if you need some more feedback or support.
Posts.Title: waiting for diagnostic mammogram and scared Janet23 mdoak

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 01:42AM mdoak wrote: Janet, here radiologists can also do biopsies, so if you meet with a radiologist perhaps he or she can do the punch biopsy. I'm not sure why the doc wouldn't be willing to do one, just to rule it out. Maybe you could put it like that: Will you do a punch biopsy just to rule out IBC on the very slim chance that's what this could be, to put my mind at rest? And if you don't see a radiologist, maybe you could ask to speak with him. We have to pick our words so carefully. The only explanation I have gotten for my breast symptoms has been perimenopause. This would be hysterical if it wasn't so serious, since I had my ovaries removed FIVE YEARS AGO. It is so wrong to feel like you have to walk a tightrope -- if you insist something is wrong, they write you off as a hysterical female. I always feel I have to pick my words carefully and sound concerned but not too concerned.... when I'm so worried I want to cry. I hope you can get the biopsy, that it's benign, and perhaps your symptoms, too, are perimenopause   M.
Posts.Title: waiting for diagnostic mammogram and scared Janet23 mdoak

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 01:28PM mdoak wrote: Spooty, I'm wondering why you're resistant to the biopsy? That's why they use the MRI for you -- to spot things that ultrasound and mammogram miss. You should definitely have the biopsy. If it is benign, you've suffered through a bit of discomfort and move on. If not, you can be grateful you caught it early. You always have the option of watching it for a few months though. Talk it over with your radiologist and see what the level of concern is, and if he/she would be comfortable with a watch and wait approach.  Melissa
Posts.Title: Very Confused (and slightly worried) Spooty barbe1958

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 07:51PM mdoak wrote: Leelee, I just responded to squid's post about her biopsy taking more time, but here is what my sister-in-law, who is a pathologist, explained to me: It takes at least 24 hours to get results, because the sample have to sit in some kind of solution for a certain number of hours. Sometimes the results are clear cut, so you can get the results in 24 hours. However, sometimes the results are not clear cut, and the pathologist has to ask for more stains to be done. This takes extra time. This doesn't mean you have cancer, not at all. Like I told squid, there are benign conditions that are difficult to distinguish from each other sometimes.  When women have really long waits, it generally means the lab has sent the slides to an expert. Again, this doesn't mean cancer. So don't draw conclusions from how long it's taking. In fact, if they were sure it was cancer you would know already, even if they needed to do more tests to determine exactly what kind, homone receptors, etc. The waiting is horrible, I know. Hang in!
Posts.Title: Punch Biopsy..How long? leelee1 leelee1

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 11:00AM mdoak wrote: Shabby, I don't know about you, but when people tell me not to worry, it makes me feel like I'm a little crazy and a whole lot alone. I think you have every reason in the world to be worried. When I had a suspicious area biopsied a month ago I was a total mess -- and when a couple people told me not to worry, I wanted to scream at them. Everything turned out B9 for me. But what I found really, really helpful was to spread the worry out a little. Talk to understanding friends. My friends really stepped up to the plate and spent quiet time with me, called a lot, took me to lunch, sent me for a massage.  Try to be as kind to yourself as you can be. Buy yourself a present, take yourself for a massage! If you need to, call your primary care physician, or whoever your healthcare point person is, and get some anxiety meds to take the edge off. Make yourself tea. Take long walks. I totally understand how you feel. And I'm crossing my fingers for you. Melissa
Posts.Title: Panic as 6 month Follow up approaches... shabby6485 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 02:12PM mdoak wrote: Cheryl, when I was waiting for my biopsy results I talked to my sister-in-law, who is a pathologist, who told me not to be surprised if the results weren't back within 48 hours like they had told me, because often pathologists send slides to be read by breast experts. She said it doesn't mean you have cancer, at all, and not to panic if that happens. From what I've read, there is not a hard and fast line between atypia and say, DCIS, and that is a VERY important distinction, since DCIS is usually treated with radiation and atypia is not. So you want your slides to be read by an expert. The wait, however, is excruciating. I am so sorry it will take so long! Melissa

Posts.Title: mri for birads 3? Lellis Lellis

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 12:58AM mdoak wrote: Dakotalife, don't worry or be mad! My sister is a radiologist, and when I was waiting on my path results she told me that often, if there is any question on a biopsy, the lab will send the slides out to a nationally-known breast specialist. This is what you want to have happen! She said it doesn't mean that you have cancer... for example, they could be trying to decide between a fibroadenoma (always benign) and a phyllodes (almost always benign). She kept telling me not to worry about it if there was a delay.  I know waiting is horribly hard; I had to wait three days and I think that took three years off my life! What I found really helpful was distraction -- a massage, out to lunch, the movies... try to be kind to yourself during this really stressful time. I'll be checking back to see what you hear. Melissa

Posts.Title: Intraluminal vs Intraductal? neochiq 2much

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 07:27PM mdoak wrote: What they mean is that it doesn't look like a fibroadenoma (common in your age group) on ultrasound, which has a very typical appearance on ultrasound -- circumscribed, oval, wider than tall, smooth edges. However, and this is a big however, just because a mass doesn't look like a fibroadenoma on ultrasound doesn't mean it isn't one. I've had fibroadenomas since I was your age, but recently had a mass that did not look like one at all on ultrasound. Bi-Rads 4b. They biopsied it and it was a fibroadenoma. Hormonal fluctuations can make them go haywire sometimes.  Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Does this sound like BC? katie31 GoldenEyes

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 05:30AM mdoak wrote: You're not being hypersensitive. Anyone would be worried in your position! A biopsy is very scary. The often-quoted figure on here is that 80% of biopsied lumps are benign. So yes, absolutely your biopsy could be benign. One helpful thing for you to do would be to get your radiology report and check your BI-RADS score. That will give you a sense of the radiologist's sense of how likely it is that your particular lump is malignant.  You might also try to see if you can get scheduled sooner for your biopsy. With a biopsy on Thursday, chances are pretty good you'll have to wait over the weekend to get your results.  I hope it all turns out well for you.
Posts.Title: Probably hypersensitive NurseBeth janet58

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 12:21PM mdoak wrote: Just take the Xanax when you're feeling really anxious. It will last for four hours or so. It's a godsend. You won't gain weight, and it will also help you sleep if you're having trouble sleeping, just take one before bed. As for the excisions, let me tell you I've had nine excisionals, some very large, 2 inches or so. There has been absolutely no difference in my breast size -- I have a B cup. Or shape, for that matter. Still look great. Take your doctor's word for it--she knows what she's doing. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Pre-Surgery Questions Linda_M SJW1

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 11:56PM mdoak wrote: It could be hormone related. My radiologist is always telling me that changes in the breasts of people our age (I'm 41) are normal (even though I had a hysterectomy 5 years ago--it makes no sense to me). I wouldn't worry about both nipples being sore -- changes that occur on both sides are usually hormonal. Good luck -- let us know what the doc says.
Posts.Title: Should I be a little worried? lawmom artistang

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2010 08:20AM - edited Dec 9, 2010 08:21AM by mdoak Sun angel,  It doesn't sound like an excisional biopsy -- it sounds like you're having a core biopsy, either vacuum assisted or not. They make a nick about 3 mm long after numbing your skin really well and put a probe in there that can cut or vacuum out little slivers of tissue about the size of a grain of rice. They'll take a bunch of those slivers out of each lump to make sure they have a good sample. It shouldn't hurt and you'll be on your feet again in an hour. I found the whole thing quite anxiety producing but not at all painful.  Best of luck, I hope it goes well.  Edited -- forgot to mention that it might be ultrasound or mammogram guided -- that's the machine he's talking about. Hope for you it's ultrasound-guided -- that is not uncomfortable at all. But lots of people do fine in the other machine as well. Melissa

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 10:04AM mdoak wrote: Irish, I have to say that it doesn't sound that good. That said, even when a doctor is sure something is cancer, sometimes a biopsy will show that it's not. I don't know of any benign conditions that ulcerate the skin, and I think your doctor is giving you clear signals to prepare yourself. Please, please take someone with you to the appointment. I don't know if you have a significant other, but if you do, I would take that person and possibly a third person, because your SO may be as unable to listen as you are. Perhaps take a tape recorder. It sounds to me like your doctors are doing a great job taking this seriously and hurrying you through the process so you won't have to wait too long. Can you call a friend and go to the movies today? I know when I was waiting for my last biopsy results it was so, so helpful to have friends keeping me busy. I had a massage, too, which was wonderfu. Please check back in as soon as you can after your results. I'm thinking about you. Melissa

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2011 08:26PM mdoak wrote: Definitely have it taken out. If anyone recommends having it taken out, take it out! As far as lumpectomies go, you probably can go back to work the next day, but might not want to. I know a lot of women schedule their surgeries for Fridays so they can have the weekend off. I don't know what your job is, but maybe you can try to schedule it for when you have a couple days off anyway.  Good luck. I think you will worry if you don't have it taken out -- I certainly would. And the lumpectomy is no big deal. I've had nine of 'em :).
Posts.Title: inconclusive path report, now for lumpectomy marticcrn mdoak

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 07:57AM mdoak wrote: Are you sure removal is scheduled for the 12th? I would think that you would need to get results first, and then make decisions based on those results. Who is doing the core biopsy? The surgeon? I guess if I were you, I would call and get some clarification about it all. Perhaps start by getting a copy of your radiologists report -- then you can see what THEY think it is. But definitely clarify what the appointment on the 12th is for. If the core biopsy shows fibroadenoma, there is probably no reason to get it removed, UNLESS the radiologist is quite sure it is cancer. But if it is cancer, you will need many more tests to figure out how widespread it it is, receptor status.... Take a deep breath. Most biopsies turn out benign. But definitely seek out more information.
Posts.Title: tests, biopsy, surgery... my head is spinning gina76 BarbaraA

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 09:43AM mdoak wrote: Cindy, what a great moniker, Wabi-sabi! Love it! I learned the whole "concordant" and "disconcordant" lingo in December, when I had a biopsy. The results have to satisfy the radiologist and explain what he saw on screen. If not, then the pathology is described as "disconcordant" and you have to push for more answers. If I were you, I would take a look at that pathology report and ask your surgeons to explain it to you in detail. My guess is the pathologist saw normal breast tissue, which obviously does not explain your mass. Other things I would ask is about the anesthesia (they don't usually do excisionals under general, but put you in twilight state), recovery time, how soon you'll get the pathology results. Let us know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 04:16PM mdoak wrote: Kimmie, find out who the "other guy" is -- is he an expert breast pathologist, the guy slides get sent to if there is any question? Posts.Title: Biopsy today now the WAIT!! kimmie44 nanadeb

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 03:20PM mdoak wrote: Hi Donnalee,  If I were you, I would start with a second opinion on your pathology report. I have learned in my research that it is difficult for pathologists to distinguish between hyperplasia, atypical hyperplasia, and DCIS -- and of course treatments differ markedly. Not only that, but different labs have different standards for telling the difference between the three! In your case, I'm not sure what MILD means, except that I would guess the pathologist may err on the side of it being the "normal" kind of hyperplasia. Definitely get a second opinion.  Melissa
Posts.Title: Mild Ductal Atypical Hyperplasia donnalee2001 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2010 06:00PM mdoak wrote: Donnalee--I meant get a second pathology opinion. Get your slides sent to another lab to be read.  Check out these links:   www.nytimes.com/2010/07/20/hea... http://networks.lww.com/pathology/blog/pnblog/pages/post.aspx?PostID=13 quote from above link: It's amazing that although we have years worth of histomorphologic, molecular, and clinical data that shows separating ADH and LG-DCIS is artificial, arbitrary, and unfounded, yet we -- and especially our professional societies -- are so unwilling to take the next logical step! You mention that "We are of course at least partly responsible for this situation because we have given these two very closely related lesions, ADH and DCIS, such radically different names."  I personally had a diagnosis of DCIS for which I had two wide excisions -- when looked at by another lab, that pathologist said atypical hyperplasia. Who was right? Hard to say. Best to have your slides looked at by another pathologist before making treatment decisions.

Keep us posted over the weekend and of course when you get your results.
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed Yet But Radiologist Not Optimistic Kasi redroks2

Posts.Content: May 19, 2011 06:18AM mdoak wrote: Wow! for one thing, your surgeon shouldn't yell at you. Have you considered getting second opinions? First, on the pathology -- adh and dcis are very close -- and second, from another surgeon? I'm not sure why your history would make him LESS likely to biopsy -- I would think it would make him MORE likely to biopsy anything new or suspicious. If I were you I'd take my films and scans and have it all looked over by someone fresh.
Posts.Title: ADH questions please pattimay lightning

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 10:38AM mdoak wrote: Tpetrone, They can't really tell if they got it all on the biopsy. I had a biopsy done (vacuum assisted) and the radiologist said he "got all he could see on the ultrasound." If it had come back ADH or something worse I would have had to have an excisional biopsy (lumpectomy) to see if they found more in the area and make sure they got clean margins if it was cancer. Good luck. My radiologist was pretty sure mine was "something" and it turned out to be a benign finding. Let us know what they say.

Posts.Content: mdoak wrote: Anyone know of any sites with pictures of breast dimpling? I have breast issue after breast issue, so many that I put off doing breast exams. So I just did my first of the month breast exam and felt a new and quite tender lump on the side of my left breast at about 3:00, almost under my arm. I didn't think that much of it since I am very lumpy and bumpy until I looked in the mirror and saw what I think is a dimple about an inch below where the lump is. I had noticed some pulling there a couple months ago but decided it was just breast sag from approaching middle age. But this is more pronounced, more like a dimple. I can only see it in certain positions, and not when I lift my arms over my head.  anyway, if anyone knows of any pics online it might be helpful. I can't go running to the doc every time I find a new thing. I'm already on high-risk monitoring and am scheduled for an MRI in June. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 07:18AM mdoak wrote: Carpediem I know exactly how you feel! And despite the fact I have extremely dense breasts with about 3 dozen fibroadenomas in them (at least, they look like fibroadenomas on ultrasound), a history of 10 biopsies and a recent very suspicious area (biopsy came back benign) he was going to put me back into "screening". Uh, no. That's when I applied to a high risk clinic -- it's a three hour drive, but I don't care. Got the appointment for February and breathed a sigh of relief. Good for you for fighting! You go! Posts.Title: Got what I wanted...but had to fight!! SarahsMom msippiqueen

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 07:48AM mdoak wrote: I have lots of fibroadenomas and they aren't painful. The other things is that they do have characteristics -- smooth, oval-shaped, movable. But just because a lump doesn't have those characteristics does not mean it's not a fibroadenoma. It could be a quickly growing fibroadenoma, for example. Fibroadenomas are not cancer, and they are not a risk factor for cancer.  If your lump has all the characteristics of a fibroadenoma on imaging they will probably have you back in six months to see if it grows, although they may biopsy it because of your age (they are more common in younger women -- but I am 41 and I have lots of them). And if you're nervous you should insist on a biopsy for piece of mind. If it doesn't look like a characteristic fibroadenoma on imaging, they will biopsy it -- still doesn't mean it's cancer. I had a wonky looking one biopsied in December -- very suspicious looking -- and it was a fibroadenoma.  Keep us posted! And good luck.
Posts.Title: Lump discovered i'm very scared... Albaforever just-starting

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 02:21PM mdoak wrote: Lintek, ALWAYS get a second opinion on a pathology report that states ADH. I have read, and doctors have told me, that different labs have different standards to distinguish between DCIS and ADH. They really are the same entity, it's just the quantity that is different. Have your slides from all of your biopsies sent to a breast pathologist to get a second opinion.  Good luck.

What did the radiologist say about the lump appearing after you hit yourself? Take care of yourself during this time, if at all possible. Get a massage, watch some movies, read some books you love, have lunch with friends. It's normal to be freaking out. Keep us posted, ok?

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 07:15AM - edited Jan 13, 2011 07:17AM by mdoak Hi Lisa, Usually whether to have a fibroadenoma removed depends on your age. Post-menopausal, they often remove them -- because fibroadenomas are usually associated with younger women. Pre-menopausal, they generally leave them alone, these days. I am a rare bird in that 20 years ago I had 9 of them removed -- they were going for 4 or 5, I can't rememember now, and found DCIS nearby -- so they removed the rest. (I recently had my slides gone over again, and the new pathologist said ADH--pathology is tricky, and standards vary on the line between DCIS and ADH from lab to lab, and hey, it was 20 years ago). I now have dozens of fibroadenomas. I am (surgically) post menopausal but because there are so many they do a watch-them approach.They have a very distinct appearance on ultrasound, so that is feasible. You certainly can have it out if you want to -- and I would if you are post-menopausal -- but otherwise, they will recommend following up in a few months to make sure it hasn't grown. Great news, that it's benign! Melissa

Posts.Title: How many of you were told.... BioAdoptMom3 marie5890

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 09:23AM mdoak wrote: I have dozens of fibroadenomas, started getting them in my late teens, and I'm now 41. I had nine of them removed at one point because they found ADH when they biopsied one. I'm now on high-risk surveillance, but not because of the fibroadenomas. The fibroadenomas all look the same on ultrasound, oval, wider rather than tall, smooth edges. Whenever one starts looking funky the radiologist biopsies it. Otherwise, they are left alone.  It can make self-exams a challenge. I recently felt a funny lump, went to the breast surgeon who felt it as well, but when she ultrasounded it, it was again a fibroadenoma, just very deep and flatter since it was up against my chest wall. Do a self-exam every month, or twice a month even until you get to know all your lumps and bumps, and then if anything changes, go right to the doc. Otherwise, if they are identified as fibroadenomas on ultrasound, you really don't need to worry. Easier said than done, eh?
Posts.Title: What are the odds of 6 lumps being benign? kennessee Laleesa

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 10:45AM mdoak wrote: Okay, breathe. I have about three dozen fibroadenomas in my breasts. The general strategy is to image them. If they look like fibroadenomas on imaging (particularly ultrasound), and you have a confirmed fibroadenoma history, they will usually schedule you for a follow up in 6 months. They may do an additional follow up 6 months after that. If the fibroadenomas don't change in size, then you should be "released" and told to come back in if there is any change. Why did you have excisions? They don't generally do that anymore -- they usually do core needle biopsies if anything looks suspicious. If anything looks suspicious on your next round of imaging, they'll schedule you for another biopsy -- core needle should be sufficient. The surgeon should be competent reading the ultrasounds or doing his own. There is no link that I know of between cervical and breast cancer. Breathe! Everything should be fine, but it's good to follow whatever follow-up protocol your doctors want.

After my biopsy, which turned out benign, suddenly the things that had seemed so annoying and difficult to deal with before didn't matter at all. That was a positive thing that came out of the entire experience. I'm glad you're finding that too. Good luck with the wait. Be good to yourself!
Posts.Title: Waiting on Biopsy results anitaph anitaph

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 06:41AM mdoak wrote: Judy,  Fibroadenomas are common, and not dangerous. They are usually very easy to spot on ultrasound. A completely reasonable policy is to go back in six months and have it imaged again. If it hasn't grown, and still looks like a fibroadenoma, you can be confident that's what it is.  Usually they don't recommend removal anymore. I've had loads of them. Worrisome, but not dangerous. Can you get insurance? I don't know what state you are in, but in New York, there are several options depending on income.
Posts.Title: Fibroademona questions jalsra alligans

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 09:26AM mdoak wrote: Nancy,  I recently had a core biopsy after having been followed for several years by the same radiologist for benign breast problems. I asked him outright what were the chances of this being cancer, and he said maybe 10%. But I got a very bad feeling from him. He had pointed out on the ultrasound the things that made this lump suspicious -- taller rather than wide, jagged edges. And then on the way out he said he thought the next step would be an MRI. Well, there are two things I want to point out. One is that my biopsy was benign, despite the jagged edges and other bad things about that lump. And the other is that the radiologist told me when he delivered the results that he had believed it was cancer--despite what he told me in that room, not that he said that--and therefore had had a second pathologist look it over as well. When I got the radiology report, he had listed the lump as BI-RADS 4B, which is somewhere around 50-50 or 60-40 (or worse, depending on if they use a 4C category or not). And the MRI comment was specifically to prepare me for what he would order when it turned out to be cancer. So I say, trust your gut about what the radiologist thinks -- I don't think it's a bad idea to be realistic, and personally I think it helps to deal with bad news when it comes if you have done a little mental preparation leading up to it. BUT even when a radiologist thinks that the biopsy has a high likelihood of being cancer (even people in the BI-RADS 5 category, which is 95% sure), it often turns out to be benign. I'll be crossing my fingers for you. Melissa

Posts.Title: biopsy tomorrow....so scared gqmom bayarea419

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 12:57PM mdoak wrote: Okay, first of all, that they recommended an excisional I think might mean the calcifications are not near the surface, so if I were you I would disregard your thoughts about the talcum powder and assume it was truly calcifications. In fact, I think experienced radiologists can spot those things. So if I were you, I would go for the biopsy, so at least you can have some peace of mind. Birads 4b is nothing to mess with. As far as radiation due to mammos goes, there is some, but it's much, much less than it used to be -- I think you can put your mind to rest about that. If you have cancer, the risk of ignoring it due to fear of radiation exposure is way more than that radiation exposure would be!  My only caveat would be the experience of your first vs. your second radiologist. Was your first radiologist a dedicated breast guy? If so, go with what he says, and get that biopsy. It's not really a difficult procedure and it should give you some piece of mind. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 09:07AM mdoak wrote: Snookie, it may be a hematoma. I had one at the site of an excisional biopsy and another at the site of a core biopsy. Definitely ask your surgeon, of course!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 04:17PM mdoak wrote: Momoschki, there is a VERY FINE LINE between DCIS and ADH. It is great news that they looked over your slides again and came to this conclusion. They may recommend that you take hormonal treatments after surgery, but all in all this is very good news. I was diagnosed with ADH nearly twenty years ago (incidental finding when they removed fibroadenomas in my 20s) and I am still, at this point, fine. My monitoring schedule at this point is every six months, mammo/ultrasound alternated with MRIs, although I haven't had an MRI yet as I'm just beginning this schedule.  Good luck with your excisional and I'm crossing my fingers for you that ADH is all the find.
